channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Venezuela, Once an Oil Giant, Reaches the End of an Era
item.description: Venezuela’s oil reserves, the world’s largest, transformed the country and the global energy market. Now its oil sector is grinding to a halt. Will it ever recover?
item.dc:creator: Sheyla Urdaneta, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children playing on abandoned fishing docks soaked in crude oil in Cabimas, Venezuela, in September.

item.title: Golden Dawn Found Guilty of Running Criminal Organization in Greece
item.description: The court tied the far-right party to a string of attacks, including the fatal stabbing of a left-wing rapper.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Iliana Magra
item.media:description: Thousands of anti-Golden Dawn demonstrators gathered outside the court in Athens on Wednesday to await the verdict.

item.title: North Korean Diplomat, Missing Since 2018, Is in Seoul, Lawmaker Says
item.description: Jo Song-gil was the North’s acting ambassador to Rome when he vanished, raising the possibility that he had become the highest-ranking official to defect to the South since 1997.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Aldo-Cietto/Farra di Soligo Parish, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jo Song-gil, second from right, in Italy in 2018. He was North Korea’s acting ambassador to Rome when he and his wife disappeared that year.

item.title: Hidden Beneath the Ocean’s Surface, Nearly 16 Million Tons of Microplastic
item.description: New research shows that the quantity of fragments embedded in the sea floor far exceeds the plastic floating on the ocean’s surface.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Plastic waste on a beach in Panama City. Scientists believe that 4.4 million to 8.8 million tons of plastic enter the sea every year.

item.title: Pompeo’s Message in Japan: Countering China Is Worth Meeting Face to Face
item.description: The American diplomat’s willingness to meet with allies in Asia, despite the crisis embroiling the White House, speaks to fears of China’s rise.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan in Tokyo on Tuesday.

item.title: Saudi Prince Accuses Palestinian Leaders of Failing Palestinians
item.description: The remarks by Prince Bandar bin Sultan, a senior member of the royal family, signaled an erosion of Saudi support for the Palestinian cause.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Prince Bandar bin Sultan, in a 2007 photo, accused the Palestinian leadership of having failed its cause.

item.title: Far-Right Extremism Taints German Security Services in Hundreds of Cases
item.description: A report by the domestic intelligence agency listed more than 1,400 instances in which soldiers, police officers and intelligence officials were suspected of extremist actions, posing “a significant danger.”
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: The German interior minister, Horst Seehofer, right, arriving Tuesday for a presentation of a report on extremism.

item.title: Distrust of China Jumps to New Highs in Democratic Nations
item.description: The sharpest rise in negative views was in Australia, while unfavorable opinions jumped in the United States and Europe, a Pew survey found.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: In many Western countries, public distrust of China and its leader, Xi Jinping, has soared in the past year.

item.title: Nerve Agent Was Used to Poison Navalny, Chemical Weapons Body Confirms
item.description: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons bolstered the assessments of European countries that a form Novichok sickened Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny posted a photograph on Monday of himself and his wife, Yulia Navalnaya, at the Charité Hospital in Berlin.

item.title: Battle Over Animal Rights Almost Brings Down the Polish Government
item.description: Legislation to ban mink farming cracked the governing coalition, forcing the country’s most powerful politician to assume formal office and exposing a struggle for control of Polish conservatism.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farmers protesting in Warsaw against a new bill introduced by the governing Law and Justice Party which includes a ban on breeding fur animals.

item.title: 2 Men Found Guilty of Aiding 2013 Kenya Mall Attack
item.description: The verdicts came seven years after 67 people were killed by Shabab militants at the upscale Westgate Mall in Nairobi.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Trying to shelter from gunfire during the attack on the Westgate mall in Nairobi in 2013.

item.title: The Gray Revolt Against Trump
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Supporters of Joe Biden in Harrisburg, Pa. last month.

item.title: Hurricane Delta Makes Landfall in Mexico
item.description: The Category 2 storm is expected pass over the Yucatán Peninsula on Wednesday before heading to the northern Gulf Coast at the end of the week.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Marie Fazio
item.media:description: A dock was closed to the public ahead of Hurricane Delta’s arrival near Playa del Carmen, Mexico, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump, U.K. Universities, Germany’s Far-Right: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump looks out from Marine One upon his return to the White House on Monday.

item.title: As the virus consumes the U.S. government’s elite, Trump presides over a capital in chaos.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cooper
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump announced Tuesday that he was ending talks with Democrats on a stimulus bill.

item.title: A senior vaccine scientist who blew the whistle on political interference resigns.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: Vaccine scientist Rick Bright resigned from the Department of Health and Human Services.

item.title: Delayed Homeland Security Report Warns of ‘Lethal’ White Supremacy
item.description: An annual assessment that a whistle-blower said was withheld for months did not hold back on the threat from violent extremists and tagged Russia as the primary source of disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: “I am particularly concerned about white supremacist violent extremists who have been exceptionally lethal in their abhorrent, targeted attacks in recent years,” Chad F. Wolf, the acting secretary of homeland security, wrote in the foreward to the assessment.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Infections have emptied the White House and sent top military officials into quarantine.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Trump, pandemic fatigue, Kyrgyzstan unrest: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: ‘It Really Was Abandonment’: Virus Crisis Grips British Universities
item.description: With no bailout forthcoming from the government, financially strapped British universities beckoned students back to campus, with predictably dire results.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students holed up in Birley hall of residence at Manchester Metropolitan University, where over a thousand students are in an enforced period of lockdown due to high numbers testing positive for Covid-19.

item.title: The Pilgrimage Must Go On: Senegal Holds Festival That Could Draw Millions
item.description: Pilgrims from across the West African country flocked to the holy city of Touba, where they slept, ate and prayed together for the Magal religious festival — despite coronavirus concerns.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Pilgrims waiting to enter at the Grand Mosque as part of the celebration of the Magal of Touba, Senegal, on Monday.

item.title: The Rev. Edoardo Tamer, Who Ministered to Syrians in War, Dies at 83
item.description: Father Tamer, a Lebanese Franciscan, chose to remain behind when given the chance to leave Syria after fighting broke out. He died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard

item.title: Nicolas Maduro of Venezuela Wins Right to Appeal Over Gold Held in U.K.
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela has been trying since 2018 to gain access to bullion deposited at the Bank of England, running into a dispute over whether Britain considers him the country’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro spoke to the United Nations General Assembly from Caracas last month, but several countries recognize his rival Juan Guaidó as Venezuela’s leader.

item.title: Mexico Prepares for Hurricane Delta
item.description: The storm, the ninth named hurricane of the Atlantic season, is expected to be “extremely dangerous” by the time it makes landfall along the northern Gulf Coast at the end of the week.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Marie Fazio
item.media:credit: Noaa/Goes, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hurricane Delta over the Caribbean Sea early on Tuesday.

item.title: E.U. Court Rules Against Hungary Law Targeting Soros-Funded University
item.description: The ruling comes as the bloc pushes back against a growing authoritarianism by the government of Viktor Orban, but is unlikely to have much effect on the ground.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Novak
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A class at Central European University in Budapest last year. It has moved most of its operations to Vienna.

item.title: Trump says he is pulling the plug on stimulus talks.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused President Trump of showing disdain for American workers after he moved to end talks over a new stimulus package.

item.title: Kyrgyzstan in Chaos After Protesters Seize Government Buildings
item.description: The country’s electoral agency annulled the results of Sunday’s disputed parliamentary elections and the president offered to mediate. But it remained unclear who was in control.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A protest against the results of a parliamentary vote on Monday.

item.title: Rational Fear
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump removed his mask after returning to the White House.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Physics Awarded to 3 Scientists for Work on Black Holes
item.description: The prize was awarded half to Roger Penrose for showing how black holes could form and half to Reinhard Genzel and Andrea Ghez for discovering a supermassive object at the Milky Way’s center.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Roger Penrose, Reinhard Genzel and Andrea Ghez are the recipients of the Nobel Prize in Physics for 2020.

item.title: New York will temporarily close nonessential businesses in parts of Queens, Brooklyn and the city’s northern suburbs.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has repeatedly warned about a possible second wave of the coronavirus, as schools and workplaces reopen in New York, and cases have risen in other states.

item.title: Britain Is Getting Ready for Its Space Race
item.description: Spurred by Brexit, London is backing companies that will build satellites and haul them into orbit.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: It has been nearly 50 years since the last British-made, satellite bearing rocket launched into space.

item.title: They Came for My Father Nearly 30 Years Ago. It Still Haunts Me.
item.description: The recent antigovernment protests in Iraq remind me of Saddam Hussein’s regime of fear and of the rebels who, like my parents, opposed it at great risk.
item.dc:creator: Hawra al-Nadawi

item.title: Top China Critic, Robert E. Lighthizer, Becomes Its Defender
item.description: Robert E. Lighthizer, President Trump’s trade negotiator, has cautioned against actions that could anger Beijing in an attempt to preserve the U.S.-China trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Robert E. Lighthizer, the United States trade representative.

item.title: Cuomo won’t approve closing businesses in 9 N.Y.C. hot spots, but will close schools in those areas on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley, Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Troy Closson and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, pictured in September, said Monday that “I’m not going to recommend or allow any New York City family to send their child to a school that I wouldn’t send my child.”

item.title: Contact tracing efforts are restricted to the two days before Trump’s diagnosis.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guests and White House staff members who attended the Rose Garden gathering on Sept. 26 will not be included in contract tracing, an official said.

item.title: New Delhi Introduces Campaign to Curb Air Pollution Ahead of Winter
item.description: In winter, India’s capital is regularly covered in toxic haze. Officials warned that filthy air could make the coronavirus pandemic more dangerous.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: New Delhi is one of the world’s most polluted cities.

item.title: Trump, Coronavirus, Armenia-Azerbaijan Conflict: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump removed his mask after returning to the White House.

item.title: Violent Protests in Kyrgyzstan Over Results of Election Marred by Vote Buying
item.description: Protesters clashed with the police in the capital, Bishkek, on Monday during a demonstration against the results of a parliamentary election. The acting prosecutor general later suggested the election result would be annulled.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:description: A large crowd gathered on Monday to protest the results of a parliamentary election in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan.

item.title: Zhao Li Sentenced in Canada to 10 Years for Killing and Dismembering Yuan Gang
item.description: Zhao Li shot his business partner outside a Vancouver mansion, and then chopped him into 108 pieces.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Vancouver mansion where Yuan Gang was killed by Zhao Li in 2015.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: President Trump is leaving the hospital. He continued to downplay the seriousness of the virus, saying: “Don’t be afraid of Covid. Don’t let it dominate your life.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Quino, Creator of Beloved ‘Mafalda’ Cartoon, Dies at 88
item.description: Joaquín Salvador Lavado drew the comic strip of the six-year-old Argentine girl, who was curious about the world and finely attuned to its injustices.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi
item.media:description: Joaquín Salvador Lavado, better known as Quino, posed with a statute of Mafalda in Buenos Aires in 2009. Upon news of his death, President Alberto Fernández of Argentina declared Oct. 1 a national day of mourning.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: President Trump, Yuko Takeuchi, Nobel Prize: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times

item.title: Excel Error Causes U.K. to Miss Nearly 16,000 Coronavirus Cases
item.description: Nearly 16,000 people who tested positive for the coronavirus disappeared from the records, another embarrassing failure for a much-criticized effort.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: A member of the National Health Service’s Test and Trace staff at a Covid-19 testing site in Bolton, Britain, last month.

item.title: Armenia-Azerbaijan Clash Takes Toll on Civilians
item.description: Stepanakert, the capital of the ethnic Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, came under bombardment on Monday as both sides used powerful, long-range weapons.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Davit Ghahramanyan/Nkr Infocenter, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo from the Republic of Nagorno-Karabakh Infocenter showing the aftermath of recent shelling.

item.title: Cuomo won’t approve closing businesses in 9 N.Y.C. hot spots, but will close schools in those areas on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley, Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Troy Closson and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, pictured in September, said Monday that “I’m not going to recommend or allow any New York City family to send their child to a school that I wouldn’t send my child.”

item.title: China Ramps Up a War of Words, Warning the U.S. of Its Red Lines
item.description: As the United States and Taiwan draw closer, state propaganda is sending the message that China will go to war if necessary.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: On Capitol Hill, the prospects for a stimulus deal before the election remain murky.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Though Speaker Nancy Pelosi said that Congressional leaders were making progress toward a deal, the two sides remain far apart.

item.title: Indonesia’s Parliament Approves Jobs Bill, Despite Labor and Environmental Fears
item.description: Parliament moved up a vote on the coronavirus stimulus bill after unions called for a national strike. Critics say it will relax rules to prevent deforestation and protect workers.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:credit: Ichal Chem/Riau Images/Barcroft Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Workers demonstrating in the city of Tangerang, Indonesia, on Monday. Parliament moved up a vote on the jobs bill after labor unions called for a national strike starting Tuesday.

item.title: What I Learned From Loving Mapo Tofu
item.description: A decades-long fascination with the much-loved Sichuan dish inspires research — and eventually a little experimentation.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Nguyen
item.media:credit: Christopher Simpson for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.
item.media:description: Mapo tofu’s origins reach back to the late 1800s.

item.title: Israel’s Coronavirus Lockdown Fuels Protests, Violence and Confusion
item.description: Last month, the country became the first to reimpose nationwide measures. But the decision has led to chaotic scenes and criticism of how its fragile coalition is handling the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A protester being detained during a demonstration against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: The Pressure to Be Perfect Turns Deadly for Celebrities in Japan
item.description: A succession of suicides has shown the burdens of a society where many feel that they must conceal their personal struggles.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Yuko Takeuchi with her co-stars and the director of the 2016 horror film “Creepy.” She died last month, apparently in a suicide.

item.title: Trump’s Condition
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Trump announced his nomination of Amy Coney Barrett in the White House Rose Garden.

item.title: The Sunset Strip Stirs Again
item.description: The legendary Los Angeles road, once a party paradise, is awakening afresh with a crop of new luxury developments.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: Paris will close its bars and many cafes for at least two weeks starting on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Patrons enjoying a drink on the terrace of a bar in Paris on Saturday.

item.title: 2020 Nobel Prize in Medicine Goes to Scientists Who Discovered Hepatitis C
item.description: Harvey J. Alter, Michael Houghton and Charles M. Rice were jointly honored for their decisive contribution to the fight against blood-borne hepatitis, a major global health problem.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu and Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Harvey Alter, Michael Houghton and Charles Rice shared the 2020 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.

item.title: In Canada, Kamala Harris, a Disco-Dancing Teenager, Yearned for Home
item.description: Senator Harris spent her adolescent years in Canada. Friends say being a California girl at a multicultural public high school in Montreal helped shape her.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky

item.title: A Portrait of a Market in India Run Solely by Women
item.description: Nupi Keithel, or Women’s Market, a 16th-century bazaar in which all of the vendors are women, is a fountainhead of social and political activism in the Indian state of Manipur.
item.dc:creator: Trishna Mohanty
